{{Infobox sports season | title = 2009â10 Pac-10 Men's Basketball Season |caption=#193980 | color =#193980 |color text =#FFFFFF | league =[[NCAA]] Division I | sport =[[College basketball|Basketball]] | logo = | pixels = | caption = | duration = | no_of_teams = 10 | attendance = | TV = | draft = | draft_link = | top_pick = | picked_by = | season = Regular Season | season_champs = | season_champ_name= Champion | league_champs = | league_champ_name= Runners-Up | second_place = | MVP = | MVP_link = Pac-10 Conference Men's Basketball Player of the Year | top_scorer = | top_scorer_link = | promote = | promoted_from = | relegate = | relegate_to = | playoffs = | playoffs_link = | conf1 = | conf1_link = | conf1_champ = | conf1-runner-up = | conf2 = | conf2_link = | conf2_champ = | conf2-runner-up = | playoffs_MVP = | playoffs_MVP_link= | finals = Tournament | finals_link = 2010 Pacific-10 Conference Men's Basketball Tournament | finals_champ = | finals_runner-up = | finals_MVP = | finals_MVP_link = Most Valuable Player | seasonslist = | seasonslistnames = Basketball | prevseason_link = | prevseason_year =[[2008-09 Pacific-10 Conference men's basketball season|08â09]] | nextseason_link = | nextseason_year =[[2010â11 Pacific-10 Conference men's basketball season|10â11]] }} {{2009â10 Pacific-10 Conference men's basketball standings}} The '''2009â10 Pacific-10 Conference men's basketball season''' began with practices on October 17, 2009 and ended with the Pac-10 Tournament on March 10â13, 2010 at the [[Staples Center]] in Los Angeles.
==Pre-season== *[[Tim Floyd]], the head coach at [[USC Trojans|USC]] resigned and was replaced by [[Kevin O'Neill (basketball)|Kevin O'Neill]], who was on the [[Arizona Wildcats|Arizona]] staff. * Pre-season media day is scheduled for October 29.
* 2009â10 PAC-10 Men's Basketball Media Poll:
:1. California (25 first place votes) :2. Washington (7) :3. UCLA (5) :4. Arizona :5. Oregon State :6. Oregon :7. Arizona State :8. Washington State :9. USC :10. Stanford
* In the ESPN/USA poll: California, No. 12; Washington, No. 13. * In the AP poll: California, No. 13; Washington, No. 14. * In the ''ESPN The Magazine'': California, No. 10; Washington, No. 13; UCLA, No. 30; Oregon State, No. 36<ref>Elena Bergeron, Matt Giles, Ian Gordon and Dan Hodes, Splite Takes, ''ESPN The Magazine'', College Basketball Preview: 2009/10</ref>
==Rankings== {{main|2009â10 NCAA Division I men's basketball rankings}}
* November 2, 2009 â Washington (0â0) #14 (AP), #13 (Coaches); California (0â0) #13 (AP), #12 (Coaches) * November 16, 2009 â Washington (3â0) #14 (AP), #14 (Coaches); California (2â0) #13 (AP), #12 (Coaches) * November 23, 2009 â Washington (4â0) #14 (AP), #14 (Coaches); California (2â2) #23 (Coaches) * November 30, 2009 â Washington (5â0) #12 (AP), #10 (Coaches); California (4â2) #25 (Coaches) * December 7, 2009 â Washington (6â1) #17 (AP), #16 (Coaches) * December 14, 2009 â Washington (6â2) #24 (AP), #21 (Coaches) * December 21, 2009 â Washington (7â2) #22 (AP), #19 (Coaches) * December 28, 2009 â Washington (9â2) #17 (AP), #16 (Coaches) * January 4, 2010 â Washington (10â3) #24 (AP), #22 (Coaches)
==Conference games== * January 23, 2010 â Five conference teams are tie for second place, and the Oregon schools are last. * January 23, 2010 â Washington has lost all road games, including four conference games. * January 31, 2009 â After playing 9 conference games, California and Arizona are tied for first place with 6 wins and 3 losses, followed by Arizona State and UCLA at third place with a 5â4 conference record. * February 4, 2010 â Four teams tied for first place, Arizona, Arizona State, California and UCLA.
==Conference tournament==
{{main|2010 Pacific-10 Conference Men's Basketball Tournament}} * March 10â13, 2010 at the [[Staples Center]] in Los Angeles, California * Tournament winner became the [[2010 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Tournament]] automatic qualifier * USC did not participate in the conference tournament this season
==Head coaches== {{col-begin}} {{col-1-of-2}} :[[Sean Miller]], Arizona :[[Herb Sendek]], Arizona State :[[Mike Montgomery]], California :[[Ernie Kent]], Oregon :[[Craig Robinson (basketball)|Craig Robinson]], Oregon State {{col-2-of-2}} :[[Johnny Dawkins]], Stanford :[[Ben Howland]], UCLA :[[Kevin O'Neill]], USC :[[Lorenzo Romar]], Washington :[[Ken Bone]], Washington State {{col-end}}
==Post season== ===[[2010 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Tournament]]=== * Thurs., Mar. 18, â No. 11 '''[[2009â10 Washington Huskies men's basketball team|Washington]]''' def. No. 6 [[2009â10 Marquette Golden Eagles men's basketball team|Marquette]] 80â78, [[San Jose, CA]] (East Region) * Fri., Mar. 19, â No. 8 '''[[2009â10 California Golden Bears men's basketball team|California]]''' def. No. 9 [[2009â10 Louisville Cardinals men's basketball team|Louisville]] 77â62, [[Jacksonville, FL]] (South Region) * Sat., Mar. 20 â '''[[2009â10 Washington Huskies men's basketball team|Washington]]''' def. [[2009â10 New Mexico Lobos men's basketball team|New Mexico]] 82â64, [[San Jose, Calif.]] (East Region) * Sun., Mar. 21 â [[2009â10 Duke Blue Devils men's basketball team|Duke]] def. [[2009â10 California Golden Bears men's basketball team|California]] 68â53, [[Jacksonville, FL]] (South Region) * Thu., Mar. 25 â [[2009â10 West Virginia Mountaineers men's basketball team|West Virginia]] def. [[2009â10 Washington Huskies men's basketball team|Washington]] 69â56, [[Carrier Dome]], [[Syracuse, New York]] (East Region)
===[[2010 National Invitation Tournament|NIT]]===
* Tues., Mar. 18 â No. 8-seed [[Jacksonville Dolphins|Jacksonville]] def. No. 1-seed [[Arizona State Sun Devils men's basketball|Arizona State]] 67â66, (First Round, Arizona State Bracket)
===[[College Basketball Invitational|CBI]]===
* Wed., Mar. 19 â [[Boston University]] def. [[2009â10 Oregon State Beavers men's basketball team|Oregon State]] 96â78, 7 p.m. (First Round, [[Gill Coliseum]])
==Highlights and notes== ===November=== * 50 former Pac-10 players were listed on the [[NBA]] opening day rosters, the average of 5.0 player per conference team tops among all conferences, with 14 former UCLA players are on the teams. * November 26, 2009 â UCLA's loss to Portland 74â47 was the worst defeat during the [[Ben Howland]] era.<ref>David Wharton, [http://www.latimes.com/sports/la-sp-ucla-basketball27-2009nov27,0,4615228.story UCLA's loss to Portland is a real drag], ''Los Angeles Times'', November 27, 2009</ref> ===December=== * December 1, 2009 â UCLA head coach Ben Howland announced that by mutual agreement, sophomore forward Drew Gordon is no longer a member of the team. Gordon will transfer at the end of the school quarter. * December 6, 2009 â After winning just one in their first four games, the [[2009-10 Oregon State Beavers men's basketball team|Beavers]] won three games in a row. ===January=== * January 3, 2010 â USC Athletic Director [[Mike Garrett]] announced that the school is forfeiting the 2007â08 season's victories, not participating in any post season tournaments in 2010 and reducing the number of scholarships for two years for violation of NCAA rules.<ref>David Wharton and Baxter Holmes, [http://www.latimes.com/sports/college/basketball/la-sp-usc-basketball4-2010jan04,0,3628718.story O.J. Mayo scandal leads to heavy sanctions for USC basketball; team 'shocked and saddened'], ''Los Angeles Times'', January 3, 2010</ref> ===March=== *Oregon State basketball coach [[Craig Robinson (basketball)|Craig Robinson]] has agreed to a two-year contract extension, through the 2015â16 season. * March 17, 2010 â California's Omondi Amoke was suspended for team rules violation going into the NCAA tournament.<ref>[http://sports.espn.go.com/los-angeles/ncb/news/story?id=5004562 Amoke suspended for rules violation], ''Associated Press'', March 17, 2010</ref> * March 17, 2010 â Oregon head coach [[Ernie Kent]]'s contract was terminated effective June 30.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2010/mar/16/sports/la-sp-college-basketball-notes-20100317 Oregon fires basketball coach Kent], ''Los Angeles Times'', March 17, 2010</ref> * March 19, 2010 â Oregon athletic director [[Mike Bellotti]] step down to join ESPN as a football analyst. ===June=== * June 10, 2010 â NCAA to release the report of its investigation of the [[2009â10 USC Trojans men's basketball team|USC basketball team]]. * June 10, 2010 â [[Colorado Buffaloes]] join the Pac-10 as its 11th member.
==Awards and honors== Three guards from the Pac-10 Conference have been named to the pre-season [[John R. Wooden Award]] list: [[Nic Wise]], Arizona; [[Jerome Randle]], California; [[Isaiah Thomas (basketball)|Isaiah Thomas]], Washington.<ref>[http://www.pac-10.org/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/082009aab.html Three Pac-10 Men's Basketball Players Named to Wooden Award Preseason List], ''Pac-10.org'', Aug. 20, 2009</ref> ===Scholar-Athlete of the Year=== * Senior [[Landry Fields]], Stanford â Scholar-Athlete of the Year, presented by [[Toyo Tires]]
===Player-of-the-Week=== {{col-begin}} {{col-1-of-2}} * Nov. 16 â Quincy Pondexter, WASH * Nov. 23 â [[Klay Thompson]], WSU<ref>[http://www.pac-10.org/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/112309aac.html Washington State's Thompson Named Pac-10 Men's Basketball Player of the Week], ''Pac-10.org'', November 23, 2009</ref> * Nov. 30 â [[Klay Thompson]], WSU<ref>[http://www.pac-10.org/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/113009aag.html Washington State's Thompson Named Pac-10 Men's Basketball Player of the Week], ''Pac-10.org'', November 30, 2009</ref> * Dec. 7 â Quincy Pondexter, WASH * Dec. 14 â Patrick Christopher, CAL * Dec. 21 â [[Alex Stepheson]], USC * Dec. 28 â Mike Gerrity, USC * Jan. 4 â Michael Dunigan, ORE * Jan. 11 â Ty Abbott, ASU {{col-2-of-2}} * Jan. 18 â Quincy Pondexter, WASH * Jan. 25 â [[Landry Fields]], STAN * Feb. 1 â Nic Wise, ARIZ * Feb. 8 â Quincy Pondexter, WASH * Feb. 15 â Jerome Randle, CAL * Feb. 22 â [[Landry Fields]], STAN * Mar. 1 â Jamal Boykin, CAL * Mar. 8 â Quincy Pondexter, WASH {{col-end}}
===All-Americans===
===All Pac-10 teams=== *Player Of The Year: Jerome Randle, California *Freshman Of The Year: Derrick Williams, Arizona *Defensive Player Of The Year: Seth Tarver, Oregon State *Most Improved Player Of The Year: Nikola Vucevic, USC *Coach Of The Year: Herb Sendek, Arizona State
